question: I was born 09/29/1932.  Immediately following cataract surgery (2000), I was told I would that lenses were inserted during the surgery and I no longer need to wear glasses. Then, to no avail, glasses were prescribed for double vision, which persisted. On attempt two (3?), my double vision was corrected with prisms in both lenses. As is my custom, I continue with annual eye exams, usually resulting in new lenses. Now, for 'floaters,'  I see Dr. Riffai, diabetic-specialist ophthalmologist. On 9/10/08, he informed me that "following cataract surgery, patients do not need lens replacements." Because my 'good' (stronger) right eye was hurting, I balked when referred to an optometrist, "With all due respect, it has been many years (1972) since I knowingly made an appointment with an optometrist."  "But, ma'am, last year you saw our Dr. (optometrist)..."  my response, "I repeat, 'With all due respect, it has been many years since I knowingly made an appointment with an optometrist."  Eventually I was referred to their in-house neuro-ophthalmologist for an appointment.   QUESTION: Am I being unreasonable? Would I be as well off to see the optometrist to check for needed lens prescription?
title: Neuro-Ophthalmology and long-term post cataract care in patient with Type 2 diabetes
